title: Ask HN: Are there any successful Tech non-profits?
text: I'm curious if there are any technology based non-profits that are cater to direct consumers where their primary business is a website/web business. The biggest one I can think of is Wikipedia; they are successful and have a very popular set of websites. Mozilla is another successful non-profit, but its primary business is not a website but a web application (Firefox). I'm not sure if Patreon is a non-profit or community benefit corporation. Do you know any others?

title: Tell HN: How to Start a Business as a Kid
text: Today the first day of summer vacation. My kids, son and daughter decided to sell water in our front-yard. We bought 32 pack of water for $6.52. They sold each bottle for 50 cents. 20 bottles were sold on the first day, they decided to donate 30% of the revenue. I'm so proud!

title: Ask HN: Are there alternative TLDs in the spirit of .dev?
text:
Hypothetical: some software dev wants to pick a domain for their professional web presence, but this dev finds Google's stewardship of th .dev tld distasteful.

Are there alternatives which communicate something similar, but are managed by more neutral entities? Or I suppose just different entities representing different values.

title: Ask HN: Why is computer generated music not as impressive as DALL·E 2?
text: Maybe composing good music is more difficult than creating a painting regardless of whether it is done by a human being or computer?

Resources to become a better Software Engineer besides coding?
text:
Hi all. I'm looking for resources, be it courses or books, on how to get better at my job.

I already know plenty of resources on how to make better code. But besides programming, I'm looking to become a better professional by itself. That is, being more reliable, to come up with better and more structured procedures, and to provide good services despite less than ideal contexts (which is, almost every company software project)

For starters, I got the book "How to Work Effectively With Legacy Code" for the technical part. My guess is to read about scrum and agile. Then about git flow and collaborative software projects. Then a bit about devops so I know what platforms support the product I'm trying to make.

Am I missing something?

Thanks in advance
